headline.main: ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Online Could Spread
headline.print_headline: ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Could Spread

docs.abstract: Farhad Manjoo State of the Art column suggests that European law requiring search engines to grant 'right to be forgotten' may spread to United States; observes that rule can  force search engines like Google's to delink results for reasons related to both privacy and accuracy; points out that measures have been strongly opposed by free speech advocates.

headline.main: Daily Report: Google Remakes Itself as Alphabet

docs.abstract: Google is adopting the Berkshire Hathaway model. The core Internet services of the company will still be called Google. And Twitter still hasn’t named a new chief executive, though the acting boss sure is acting like someone who plans to stick around.

docs.snippet: The newly appointed chief executive owes his new job to his success in making Google products easier to use and thus more popular....
docs.lead_paragraph: The newly appointed chief executive owes his new job to his success in making Google products easier to use and thus more popular.

headline.main: Sundar Pichai Will Lead Google With Users in Mind
headline.print_headline: Leader With Users in Mind Will Take the Helm at Google

docs.abstract: Profile of Sundar Pichai, new chief of operations at Google who is known for his intense focus on user experience; Pichai's rise at Google can be tied to his success in making Google products easier to use and consequently more popular.

byline.contributor: David Streitfeld reported from San Francisco and Mike Isaac from New York. Claire Cain Miller contributed reporting from San Francisco.
byline.original: By DAVID STREITFELD and MIKE ISAAC

docs.snippet: From Google’s start, Larry Page has been afflicted with a desire for two competing corporate virtues: focus and expansiveness....
docs.lead_paragraph: From Google’s start, Larry Page has been afflicted with a desire for two competing corporate virtues: focus and expansiveness.

headline.main: With Google as Alphabet, a Bid to Dream Big Beyond Search
headline.print_headline: A Bid to Divide and Conquer

docs.abstract: Farhad Manjoo State of The Art column examines Google's decision to reorganize as Alphabet Inc; observes that move will free company to more aggressively pursue opportunities beyond its core search business, and that change could be widely emulated in tech industry should it prove successful.

docs.snippet: Under the new name, Alphabet, the company is signaling that it has essentially become a collection of disparate businesses....
docs.lead_paragraph: Under the new name, Alphabet, the company is signaling that it has essentially become a collection of disparate businesses.

headline.main: Google to Reorganize as Alphabet to Keep Its Lead as an Innovator
headline.print_headline: Google Mixes a New Name and Big Ideas

docs.abstract: Google is reorganizing under new name Alphabet, separating its profitable businesses from its speculative projects; change is attempt to keep company innovative; chief executive Larry Page will run Alphabet along with co-founder Sergey Brin.

docs.snippet: When Google splits into smaller parts under an umbrella company called Alphabet, one section of the company will be extremely profitable. The rest? That has not been explained....

headline.main: Daily Report: What Google’s Reinvention Means Is Far From Clear

docs.abstract: When Google splits into smaller parts under an umbrella company called Alphabet, one section of the company will be extremely profitable. The rest? That has not been explained.

docs.snippet: The Internet giant has been short on details about how its reconfiguration as the entity Alphabet will work. But a look at Nest Labs may provide some clues....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Internet giant has been short on details about how its reconfiguration as the entity Alphabet will work. But a look at Nest Labs may provide some clues.

headline.main: Google Goal in Restructuring as Alphabet: Autonomy
headline.print_headline: Autonomy Seen as Goal of New Google

docs.abstract: Observers say Google's reorganization under Alphabet conglomerate is aimed at creating greater autonomy for individual entities like Google Inc and Nest, shift that could foster spirit of entrepreneurialism and innovation; financial details of new company remain unclear, especially whether funds from profitable businesses will be diverted to fuel speculation elsewhere.

docs.snippet: The restructuring could fund world-changing research, but only so long as the underlying business remains a cash cow....
docs.lead_paragraph: The restructuring could fund world-changing research, but only so long as the underlying business remains a cash cow.

headline.main: Is the New Google More Like Berkshire Hathaway, General Electric or AT&T?
headline.print_headline: Alphabet, Viewed Through the Lens of 3 Companies

docs.abstract: The Upshot; legacies of conglomerates Berkshire Hathaway, General Electric and AT&T offer three potential analogies that could inform future of Alphabet, newly-created parent company for Google and its other properties.

docs.snippet: Alphabet is Google’s new entity that will house its search and other units, but other businesses — including a BMW subsidiary — have already staked a claim on the name....
docs.lead_paragraph: Alphabet is Google’s new entity that will house its search and other units, but other businesses — including a BMW subsidiary — have already staked a claim on the name.

headline.main: Alphabet? Google Might Get Some Letters
headline.print_headline: Alphabet? Google Might Get Some Letters

docs.abstract: Alphabet, name selected by Google for its new parent entity, is already a component of trademarks, websites and other company names; BMW owns domain name alphabet.com; some businesses find nominal association with Google flattering, but legal action could still be forthcoming.

headline.main: Europe Gives Google More Time to Respond to Antitrust Charges
headline.print_headline: More Time for Google to Answer Europeans

docs.abstract: European Commission extends Google's deadline to answer claims that it favored its own comparison shopping search over those of rivals until end of August; European officials and antitrust lawyers say company's move to reorganize its business units under new name Alphabet will not affect antitrust case.

headline.main: Malaysia: Seeking to Curb Social Media
headline.print_headline: Asia; Malaysia: Seeking to Curb Social Media

docs.abstract: Malaysian Communications Minister Salleh Said Keruak says Facebook, Google and Twitter will be asked to curb content to preserve public safety; request is latest effort to quash dissent triggered by accusations of graft at state investment fund, which has proved problematic for Prime Min Najib Razak.

headline.main: Unicorns Hunt for Talent Among Silicon Valley’s Giants
headline.print_headline: Upstarts Raiding Giants for Staff in Silicon Valley

docs.abstract: Silicon Valley start-up companies valued at more than $1 billion have been trying to poach employees from tech giants like Google with generous equity and pay packages; these so-called unicorn companies, like Uber and Airbnb, have been on hiring sprees, and while focus is on strategic technologies, poaching is not limited to engineers; scale of recruiting battle has been increased by sheer number of unicorn companies, which stands at more than 124.

headline.main: Rousting the Book Pirates From Google
headline.print_headline: Rousting the Book Pirates From Google

docs.abstract: David Segal The Haggler column describes looking into claims of rampant e-book piracy on Google Play; notes that e-book piracy began when store offered authors accounts from which they could list self-published titles; accounts, for some, became channels through which they could pirate, and sell, books they had not authored.
